key: _gemini-2-5-pro__Which method of improving soil organic matter is the most cost-effective: adding mulch or growing cover crops?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Four action documents were found that contain information on improving soil organic matter.
[Statement 2]: None of the found documents contain any information on the cost-effectiveness of the methods for improving soil organic matter.
[Statement 3]: A replicated trial from Canada, Poland, and Spain showed that adding mulch to crops, in the form of shredded paper, municipal compost, or straw, increased soil animal and fungal numbers, diversity, and activity.
[Statement 4]: One of the replicated trials from Canada, Poland, and Spain also found that mulch improved soil structure and increased soil organic matter.
[Statement 5]: Two controlled trials from India and South Africa found that soil organic matter increased under cover crops.
[Statement 6]: A trial from Germany found cover crops had no effect on soil organic matter.
[Statement 7]: A study found that growing cover crops resulted in more diverse nematode communities.
[Statement 8]: Another study found greater microbial biomass under ryegrass compared to a ryegrass/vetch cover crop mix.
[Statement 9]: A randomized, replicated experiment from Belgium found increased microbial biomass when crop remains and straw were added to the soil.

[Statement 1]: No action documents were found that directly address the use of drone-based precision fertilizer application and its effect on soil microbial biomass.
[Statement 2]: Several studies address topics related to fertilizer application and its effects.
[Statement 3]: Five controlled trials and one study found higher microbial biomass and activity in soils with a mix of manure and inorganic fertilizers.
[Statement 4]: Manure alone also increased microbial biomass.
[Statement 5]: One trial found that mixed amendments were more effective at reducing the size of cracks in dry soil than inorganic fertilizers alone or no fertilizer.
[Statement 6]: Fourteen studies found that areas treated with organic fertilizers supported higher plant diversity and cover.
[Statement 7]: Fourteen studies found that areas treated with organic fertilizers increased earthworm abundance or diversity, biomass and density.
[Statement 8]: Fourteen studies found that areas treated with organic fertilizers increased the abundance and/or species richness of some or all invertebrates investigated.
[Statement 9]: Five studies found positive effects of reducing or stopping fertilizer applications on invertebrates, Eurasian skylark, or plants.
[Statement 10]: Four studies found no or no consistent effects on some invertebrates and farmland birds from reducing or stopping fertilizer applications.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: There is no information available in the action documents regarding the social barriers that prevent farmers from adopting crop rotation in Canada.
[Statement 2]: The available information primarily focuses on the effects of crop rotation.
[Statement 3]: Nine studies from Canada and the USA, along with one review, looked at how crop rotation affects pest or pathogen populations in potato farming.
[Statement 4]: Some studies found that crop rotation reduced pest populations and crop diseases.
[Statement 5]: Another study found that pest populations increased with crop rotation.
[Statement 6]: Four other studies found both increases and decreases in pest populations, depending on the rotation crops used and other treatments.
[Statement 7]: One study found that crop rotation had no effect on pest populations.
[Statement 8]: Three out of five studies from Canada and the USA found that crop rotation increased crop yield in some years or with certain rotation crops.
[Statement 9]: Two studies found that yield both increased and decreased depending on the rotation crops used.
[Statement 10]: One study found that crop rotation increased profit.
[Statement 11]: One study found that fewer insecticide treatments were needed on rotated plots.
[Statement 12]: Several studies in Canada and other countries found that including legumes in crop rotations increased the number of microbes and the diversity of different soil animals.
[Statement 13]: Including forage crops in rotations was found to reduce rainwater runoff and soil loss in one Canadian trial.
[Statement 14]: Crop rotation, especially with legumes, was found to increase soil organic carbon and soil organic matter in several studies.
[Statement 15]: One study found that longer crop rotations led to lower soil organic matter levels.
[Statement 16]: Some studies in Europe found less organic matter in soils with crop rotations compared to continuous crops.
[Statement 17]: A study in Syria found more organic matter in soils with crop rotations compared to continuous crops.
[Statement 18]: The effects of crop rotation on soil nutrients like nitrogen and phosphorus were inconsistent across various studies.
[Statement 19]: The impact of crop rotation on microbial biomass and greenhouse gas emissions also varied, with some studies showing positive effects, some negative, and some no difference at all.
[Statement 20]: There were mixed results regarding the effect of crop rotation on soil erosion and aggregation.
[Statement 21]: The pH levels in soils with or without crop rotations were found to be similar in two studies.
